awd_titl_txt: Searching for Abrupt Climate Change Precursors Using Ultra High Resolution Ice Core Analysis
awd_abstract_narration: The project will undertake an ultra high resolution, multi-parameter investigation of past climate to develop predictors for future abrupt climate change through identification of the "tipping points" which occur prior to an abrupt climate change events.  Ultra-high resolution (up to 4 micron) ice core records will be produced -- well beyond the ~1cm resolution currently available -- using continuous flow injection into both a Thermo Element 2 ICP-MS and a Picarro Inc. L-2130-I H2O isotope analyzer sampled using a newly developed state-of-the-art cryocell chamber integrated with digital image recording and annotating software.  The PI will look for precursors that reveal evidence of changes in, for example, the timing and magnitude of temperature, precipitation and atmospheric circulation from multi-decadal down to hundreds of sampling levels per year.  The project will train students to be well versed in advanced laboratory and numerical modeling methods.  Students will learn data reduction and visualization algorithms while also helping to provide a data stream that has broad applicability to climate.  Cyberinfrastructure developed under NSF funding to the Climate Change Institute will be used to store, process, and visualize this high volume of ice core data while also making the information available to the public with high transparency for climate change use and attribution.

por.por_cntn:
Abrupt climate change (ACC) events were only discovered and verified in Greenland ice core records two decades ago. During some ACC events, the climate system experienced rapid (changes occurring within several years) reorganizations that impacted regional, and in some cases global temperature fields, atmospheric circulation patterns, and dust levels in the atmosphere. These ACC events heralded global warming/cooling and massive shifts in the atmospheric circulation.

The main research focus of this project was to improve the understanding of ACC events and their precursors so that future ACC events can be predicted and their impacts hopefully mitigated. Our research was based on the reexamination of previously identified ACC events from the Greenland Ice Sheet Project 2 (GISP2) utilizing new laser ablated sampling technology that has allowed us to go from classic ~1 cm sampling resolution to ultra high resolution 121 micron sampling, thus providing sub-seasonal examination of records that previously were only identifiable at annual or coarser resolution. We also examined ACC events in several West Antarctic (e.g., Siple Dome A, Roosevelt Island Climate Evolution, West Antarctic Ice Sheet Divide) ice cores..

The glaciochemical species measured from ice core records are well-established paleoclimate proxies for dust and volcanic sources, intensities and directions of atmospheric circulation patterns, sea ice cover and many other climate parameters. In the past, sampling resolution has been one of the limiting factors obstructing the examination of deep or highly compressed ice core samples. Instrumentation and sampling methods developed during the course of the project allowed further refinement of ultra high resolution sampling technology developed through a W.M. Keck Foundation award. The novel sampling framework added to the W.M. Keck ice core laser ablation chemical sampling method by this project yielded continuous recording of co-registered physical properties  (e.g., ice crystal sizes, orientations, locations of triple junction points) and included new high resolution stable water isotopes sampling. The new 2.5 mm ice core stable water isotopes sampling resolution represents a significant leap in ice core-based stable water isotope sampling research, though more records are needed to fully understand the effects of diffusion or recrystallization of the ice matrix on signal preservation.  The newly collected ultra high resolution data resulting from this project also initiated developments in our in-house generated ice core time series software tools and techniques. While interpretation and publications of the entire new massive data array will take some time, we have already demonstrated in several published peer–review papers that the newly developed instrumentation successfully captures seasonal layers and finer changes in chemical signal magnitudes in highly compressed ice core samples, and improves understanding of how ACC events are captured in ice core records.

The newly collected information on ACC events from Greenland and Antarctic ice cores supports previous understanding and provides specific data on climate signal manifestation. Further refinement of these associations in the context of specific ocean-atmosphere change scenarios will help to improve understanding of the dynamics of potential future rapid climate change scenarios under anthropogenically increased greenhouse gas scenarios.

The project directly contributed to the research of two MSc graduate students and three PhD students. All project participants including undergraduate student assistants received laboratory, data mining and interpretational skills through involvement with this project.  Numerous public lectures describing project results were given to scientific and public audiences worldwide.
